content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. A large vat is initially filled with a saltwater solution. A solution with a higher concentration of salt flows into the vat, and solution flows out of the vat at the same rate. The number of pounds of salt in the vat at time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes is modeled by the function <math alttext="A"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that satisfies the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of A, with respect to t, equals, 6 minus, 0.02 A"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>A</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>0.02</mn><mi>A</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. At time <math alttext="t equals 10"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes, the vat contains 50 pounds of salt. (a) Write an equation for the line tangent to the graph of <math alttext="A"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="t equals 10"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Use the tangent line to approximate the number of pounds of salt in the vat at time <math alttext="t equals 12"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. A large vat is initially filled with a saltwater solution. A solution with a higher concentration of salt flows into the vat, and solution flows out of the vat at the same rate. The number of pounds of salt in the vat at time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes is modeled by the function <math alttext="A"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that satisfies the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of A, with respect to t, equals, 6 minus, 0.02 A"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>A</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>0.02</mn><mi>A</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. At time <math alttext="t equals 10"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes, the vat contains 50 pounds of salt. (a) Write an equation for the line tangent to the graph of <math alttext="A"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="t equals 10"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Use the tangent line to approximate the number of pounds of salt in the vat at time <math alttext="t equals 12"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes.

(b) Show that <math alttext="A of t, equals, 300 minus, 250 times e raised to the 0.2 minus, 0.02, t power"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>300</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>250</mn><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0.2</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>0.02</mn><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> satisfies the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of A, with respect to t, equals, 6 minus, 0.02 A"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>A</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>0.02</mn><mi>A</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> with initial condition <math alttext="A of 10, equals 50"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>50</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c) The flow of solution into the vat is stopped, and the solution is drained. The depth of solution in the vat is modeled by the function <math alttext="h"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that satisfies the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of h, with respect to t, equals, negative k, times the square root of h"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow><msqrt><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="h of t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in meters, <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the number of minutes since draining began, and <math alttext="k"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is a constant. If the depth of the solution is 16 meters at time <math alttext="t equals 0"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes and 4 meters at time <math alttext="t equals 30"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes, what is <math alttext="h of t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in terms of <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

topic.text: 4.6: Approximating Values of a Function Using Local Linearity and Linearization

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
